1.title: Maximum Landing Mass (MLM) is best defined as.

variants.a: Maximum permissible total mass on landing under normal operating conditions.
variants.b: Maximum permissible total mass on landing.
variants.c: Maximum permissible total mass on the approach to land.
variants.d: Maximum permissible total mass on taxiing to park.

2.title: What V speed is it important not to exceed if sudden full-pitch, nose-up, control movements are planned, and why?

variants.a: VA, sudden control movements can cause structural damage.
variants.b: VD, sudden control movements can cause a departure from controlled flight.
variants.c: VNE, sudden control movements can cause structural damage.
variants.d: VFB, sudden control movements can cause a departure from controlled flight.

3.title: What is the colour of the caution speed range on an Air Speed Indicator, and what must the pilot be mindful of when operating in this range?

variants.a: Yellow. -This speed range should not be entered unless the air is smooth. Any manoeuvres should be made using small and gentle control inputs.
variants.b: Green. -Stalls, airframe deformations, and/or structural damage may occur in this range if the pilot uses abrupt and full control deflections.
variants.c: Yellow -Stalls, causing airframe deformations, and/or structural damage may occur in this range if the pilot uses abrupt and full control deflections.
variants.d: Green. -Control flutter may occur if turbulence is encountered.

4.title: What name is given to the load at which the aircraft structure will fail?

5.title:
An aircraft which has been grossly overloaded will:
1.require increased take-off and landing distances.
2.Have a higher stalling speed.
3.Have a reduced maximum level flight speed.
4.Have increased range and endurance.
5.Have a reduced rate of climb and operating ceiling. Which of the above are correct?

6.title: Maximum Zero Fuel Mass (MZFM) is best defined as.

variants.a: Maximum permissible mass of the aircraft with no useable fuel.
variants.b: Maximum permissible mass of the aircraft with no passengers or fuel.
variants.c: Maximum permissible mass of the aircraft with no crew or fuel.
variants.d: Maximum permissible mass of the aircraft without occupants and baggage.

7.title: Maximum Take Of Mass (MTOM) is defined best as:

variants.a: Maximum permissible total mass at the start of the take off run.
variants.b: Maximum permissible total mass prior to taxiing.
variants.c: Maximum permissible total mass prior to take off.
variants.d: Maximum permissible total mass at the point of rotation.

8.title: Which of the following situations may, under certain conditions, result in structural damage occurring?

variants.a: An aircraft being flown above its maximum all up mass.
variants.b: An aircraft in the utility category being flown at its maximum permissible mass.
variants.c: An aircraft being flown above its maximum landing mass.
variants.d: An aircraft in the normal category being flown at its maximum permissible mass.

9.title: Never exceed speed (Vne) is the red radial line on the ASI and marks the speed at which

variants.a: Flight is permitted in smooth conditions only.

10.title: When flying in very rough air what is the maximum speed to be adopted in order to avoid overstressing the airframe?

11.title: Your aircraft has an oil reservoir with a capacity of 3 imp/gal which is positioned 20 inches aft of the datum. Given that the oil weighs 9.1 lbs/gal, the reservoir will possess a moment of:-

12.title: Assuming the aircraft is at rest on the ground, what term best describes image 'D'?

13.title:
An aircraft is loaded such that its C of G is on the aft limit:-
I The stalling speed decreases, which is a negative factor.
II Range and endurance decrease, which are negative factors.
III The stall risk increases, which is a negative factor.
IV Stick forces increase, which is a negative factor.

variants.a: Only II and III are correct.
variants.b: All of the above are correct.
variants.c: Only I and IV are correct.
variants.d: Only II and IV are correct.

14.title: Certification requirements stipulate that when loading a light aircraft:

variants.a: The C of G should remain within the defined limits and the Maximum Take-off Mass must not be exceeded.
variants.b: All seats, baggage compartments and fuel tanks are contained within the C of G limits so that it is impossible to load the aircraft beyond its limits.
variants.c: With maximum traffic load and full fuel the aircraft will not exceed the authorised Maximum Takeoff Mass.
variants.d: That the Maximum Take-off Mass is not exceeded, and the CofG remains at least 5% inside the C of G limits.

15.title: The Maximum Take-off Mass of an aircraft may be limited by:-

variants.a: Structural design load limits and or runway length, altitude and temperature.
variants.b: The authorised performance category of the aircraft, i.e. utility / normal / aerobatic.
variants.c: The airworthiness condition of the aircraft.

16.title: DOM (Dry operating Mass) is defined as:

variants.a: The total mass of the aircraft ready for a specific type of operation including crew, crew baggage and special equipment but excluding useable fuel and traffic load.
variants.b: The total mass of the aircraft ready for a specific type of operation including: crew and crew baggage, catering and removable passenger service equipment and fuel.
variants.c: The total mass of the aircraft ready for a specific type of operation including: crew and crew baggage, catering and removable passenger service equipment and traffic load.
variants.d: The total mass of the aircraft ready for a specific type of operation including: crew and crew baggage, catering and removable passenger service equipment, traffic load and fuel.

17.title: An aircraft loaded in a dangerous manner, so that its C of G is beyond its forward limit will:

variants.a: Have both an increased longitudinal stability and stalling speed.
variants.b: Require less effort to flare when landing.
variants.c: Require less effort to rotate on take off.
variants.d: Have both an increased range and endurance.

18.title: The flight characteristics of an aircraft which has its C of G at the forward limit will be:-

variants.a: Insensitivity to Pitch Control and great Longitudinal Stability.
variants.b: Insensitivity to Pitch Control and little Longitudinal Stability.
variants.c: sensitivity to Pitch Control and little Longitudinal Stability.
variants.d: sensitivity to Pitch Control and great Longitudinal Stability.

19.title: An aircraft weighing 2000 lbs with a total CofG moment of + 169400 lb in uplifts 440 lbs of fuel. If the effective arm of the fuel is 88.5 inches aft of the datum, what will be the aircraft's new mass and C of G moment?

20.title: You plan to carry your aircraft's maximum permissible 'Traffic Load'. Your principal consideration during your flight planning will be that:-

variants.a: Your fuel load may have to be limited to prevent you exceeding the Maximum All Up Weight / Mass.
variants.b: It is mandatory to carry a full fuel load when carrying passengers.
variants.c: The fuel load is accounted for in 'Traffic Load' calculations.
variants.d: The 'Traffic Load' may have to be reduced to allow for the full fuel load.

variants.a: Is the total mass of passengers, baggage and freight.
variants.b: Includes drinkable water and lavatory chemicals.
variants.c: Is the total mass of passengers, baggage and freight and fuel.

22.title:
The consequences of operating an aeroplane with the C of G beyond the aft limit will be:-
I On the ground the aircraft would be tail heavy and passenger or crew movement or fuel usage could make it tip up.
II The flying controls would be too sensitive increasing the risk of a tail strike at rotation.
III The tendency to stall would increase and it may be impossible to achieve 'hands off' balanced flight.
IV Recovery from a spin would be much more difficult.

variants.c: Only statements I and IV are correct.
variants.d: Only statements II and III are correct.

23.title: Assuming the aircraft is at rest on the ground, what term best describes image A'?

24.title: In which Category. utility or Normal, would you expect to operate the aircraft represented in the attached CofG /Moment Envelope if its mass is 2100 lbs and its CofG Moment 90,000 lb inches?

25.title: What is used as the aircraft reference for the C of G limit, and upon which axis is that limit found? Axis / Reference

26.title: C of G limits are set by the manufacturer and:

27.title:
Your aircraft has:-
A Take-off Mass of = 2353 tbs
A calculated C of G for departure = 89.75 inches aft of the datum
An estimated fuel burn = 200 lbs with a C of G 85.00 inches aft of datum.
The position of the C of G on landing will be?

28.title: The Centre of Gravity range of most aircraft reduces as the aircraft mass increases, as a result of:-

variants.a: The forward C of G limit moving rearwards to reduce stability.
variants.b: The aft C of G limit moving forward to increase stability.
variants.c: The aft C of G limit moving rearwards to extend the static margin.
variants.d: The static margin moving forward to reduce manoeuvrability.

29.title: When calculating the MZFM (maximum zero fuel mass), the following are included:-

30.title: What effect will a higher aircraft mass have on rotate speed and take-off safety speed?

variants.c: It will increase rotate speed and decrease take off safety speed.
variants.d: It will decrease rotate speed and increase take off safety speed.

31.title: What is the effect of runway slope on the take-off?

variants.a: An uphill slope will increase the take-off distance.
variants.b: An uphill slope will increase the take-off performance.
variants.c: A downhill slope will increase the take-off distance
variants.d: A downhill slope will decrease the take-off performance.

32.title: That part of a runway surface which is used for normal operations during take-off, excluding any clearway or stopway, is referred to as:-

33.title: If the density of the atmosphere is reduced, the take-off distance will be:-

34.title: If the density of the air is increased above ISA conditions, the effect will be:-

variants.d: To decrease just the take-off run.

35.title: When the density of the atmosphere is relatively low, the resulting reduction in:-

variants.a: Both lift and engine power will require a longer take-off distance.
variants.b: Thrust and drag has no apparent effect on the take-off distance required.
variants.c: Drag will permit the use of greater flap angles.
variants.d: Drag offsets the loss of engine power giving improved acceleration.

36.title: The main reason for taking off into wind is to:-

variants.a: Decrease the ground speed of the aircraft at lift-off.
variants.b: Decrease the take off distance available (TODA).
variants.c: Increase the ground speed of the aircraft.

37.title: Increasing the aeroplane's gross weight will have what effect on the take-off?

variants.a: Increase the stall speed and the take-off run required.
variants.b: Decrease the stall speed and increase the take-off run required.
variants.c: Increase the stall speed and decrease the take-off run required.
variants.d: Decrease the stall speed and the take-off run required.

38.title: What is the reason for increasing the speed in a prolonged climb:-

variants.a: To increase the flow of air through the engine and keep it cool.
variants.b: To maintain the best rate of climb speed.
variants.c: To reduce the noise of the aircraft in sensitive areas.
variants.d: To maintain the best angle of climb speed.

variants.a: The greatest increase in altitude in a given period of time.
variants.c: The maximum increase in height in the shortest horizontal distance.

40.title: To gain the greatest amount of height in the shortest time period the aircraft should be flown at:-

variants.a: The best rate of climb speed (Vy).
variants.c: The best angle of climb speed (Vx).
variants.d: At the speed for maximum endurance.

41.title: Calculate the rate of climb for an aircraft operating at 5000 ft with an outside air temperature of 0°C.

42.title: Increasing the mass (and, therefore, weight) of the aircraft will:-

variants.a: Decrease the rate and angle of climb.
variants.b: Increase the rate and angle of climb.
variants.c: Increase the rate of climb and decrease the angle of climb.
variants.d: Decrease the rate of climb and increase the angle of climb.

43.title: The best rate of climb is achieved:-

variants.a: When flying at the speed for maximum excess power available.
variants.b: When flying at the speed for maximum excess thrust available.

44.title: The indicated air speed for the best rate of climb when climbing to cruise altitude will tend to:-

45.title: The lift produced by the wing of an aeroplane that is climbing and maintaining a constant airspeed will be:-

46.title:
An aircraft cruising at 2000 ft is cleared to climb to 8000 ft. Calculate the time taken in minutes, the fuel used in gallons and the distance flown during the climb. The temperature is standard and the wind is calm. 
Time (mins)       Fuel (gal)      Distance (nm)

variants.c: The greatest increase in altitude in a given period of time.
variants.d: The maximum horizontal distance for a given vertical distance.

48.title: If the centre of gravity is moved aftwards. The effect is?

variants.b: A stronger lift-weight couple which requires more tail plane down force.

49.title: What speed should be flown for maximum range:

50.title: What is the maximum range speed for a piston engine aircraft?

variants.c: At a higher speed than Vno and at the lowest safe altitude.
variants.d: At a higher speed than VNOand at the lowest safe altitude.

51.title: In order to maximise the glide range, the aircraft should be flown:

variants.a: At low angles of attack at Vmd
variants.b: At high angles of attack at Vmd.
variants.c: At low angles of attack at Vmp.
variants.d: At a negative angle of attack at Vmd.

52.title: A pilot wishes to fly at a speed which will give him maximum range. He knows that he is flying with a tailwind. How will the speed selected by the pilot compare with the maximum range speed for still air?

variants.a: It will be decreased by a margin slightly less than the amount of tailwind.
variants.b: It will be increased by a margin slightly less than the amount of tailwind.
variants.c: It will be the same as for still air.
variants.d: It will be decreased by a margin slightly more than the amount of tailwind.

53.title: Which of the following cases will result in a reduced performance and possibly exceed the structural limitations of the aircraft?

variants.a: An aircraft that is operated above its maximum all up weight.
variants.b: An aircraft that is stalled at its maximum all up weight.
variants.c: An aeroplane that is operated above its maximum all up landing weight
variants.d: An aircraft with a higher take-off mass than a landing mass.

54.title: What is the effect of a headwind on the glide angle and glide distance?

variants.a: Glide angle will increase and glide distance decrease.
variants.b: Glide angle will remain the same and glide distance will remain the same.
variants.c: Glide angle will increase and glide distance increase.
variants.d: Glide angle will decrease and glide distance decrease.

55.title: What speed must be flown to aQain the maximum cruise endurance?

56.title: The maximum glide range will be achieved by:-

variants.a: a relatively low angle of attack being maintained.
variants.b: A relatively high angle of attack being maintained.
variants.c: A negative angle of attack being maintained.

57.title: If weight is increased, the range of the aircraft will be:

variants.d: Reduced if no increase in lift is achieved.

58.title: A wing contaminated by a small amount of ice will produce:-

variants.a: More drag, more weight and less lift.
variants.c: An increase in both lift and drag co-efficient.
variants.d: An increase in weight and decrease in drag.

59.title: When gliding for maximum range, an aircraft with a greater weight will:-

variants.a: Have a faster descent speed but the same descent angle.
variants.d: Have a faster descent speed and a reduced descent distance.

60.title: What speed must be flown to aQain the maximum cruise range?

61.title: What would be the effect of an increase in temperature upon the air density and aircraft performance?

variants.a: Reduced density and reduced aircraft performance.
variants.b: Increased density and reduced aircraft performance.
variants.c: Increased density and increased aircraft performance.
variants.d: Reduced density and an increase in aircraft performance.

62.title: Compared to gliding in still air, the effect of a tailwind will:-

variants.a: Increase the glide range but have no effect on the glide endurance.
variants.b: Decrease the glide angle and decrease the rate of descent
variants.c: Have no effect on the glide range or the rate of descent.
variants.d: Increase the glide angle and increase the glide range.

63.title: Which of the speeds indicated by A, B, C or D should be flown for maximum endurance?

64.title: During straight and level flight, any increase in lift causing an imbalance in the equilibrium of forces is compensated for by:

variants.a: A downward force on the tailplane.

65.title: What is the effect of an increase in mass on the stall speed and landing distance required?

variants.a: Increased stall speed and increased landing distance.
variants.b: Increased stall speed and decreased landing distance.
variants.c: Decreased stall speed and decreased landing distance.
variants.d: Decreased stall speed and increased landing distance.

66.title: When landing, if an aircraft's true air speed is significantly less than the true ground speed then the aircraft is experiencing:

67.title: If the approach and landing speed is higher recommended speed in the aircraft manual the effect will be that:

variants.a: The landing distance will be increased.
variants.b: The landing distance will be decreased,
variants.d: The landing distance will be Unaffected.

68.title: What effect would a 2% downslope have on the landing distance required?

69.title: Compared to landing on a level runway, what would be the effect of landing on a downward sloping runway?

variants.a: The landing distance will be increased.
variants.c: The landing distance will be decreased.
variants.d: The landing distance will be Unaffected.

70.title: If the stalling speed in the landing configuration is 55 knots. VREFwould be approximately:

71.title: The Vref to be attained by the landing screen height of 50ft must be:

variants.a: 1.3 times the stalling speed in the landing configuration.
variants.b: 1.15 times the stalling speed in the take off configuration.
variants.c: 1.43 times the stalling speed in the landing configuration.

72.title: If the aircraft mass is increased by 15%, the landing distance required will increase approximately:

73.title: Landings are carried out into wind because:

variants.a: It will reduce the ground speed and reduce the landing distance required.
variants.b: It increases the ground speed and reduces the landing distance required.
variants.c: It decreases the ground speed and reduces the landing distance available
variants.d: It gives the pilot greater control over the aircraft at lower speeds.

79.title: The easiest way to determine the pressure altitude is setting an altimeter to

variants.b: The airport elevation and reading the altitude.
variants.c: The airport elevation and reading the value in the barometric window.
variants.d: Zero and reading the value in the barometric window.

80.title: Basic reason for calculating the density altitude is determining

variants.c: The flight levels above the transition altitude.
variants.d: The safe altitude over mountainous terrain.

variants.a: The altitude indicated when the barometric pressure scale is set to 1013.2 hPa.
variants.b: The indicated altitude corrected for position and installation error.
variants.c: The indicated altitude corrected for nonstandard temperature and pressure.

82.title: Under which condition will pressure altitude be equal to true altitude?

variants.b: When the atmospheric pressure is 1013.2 hPa.
variants.c: When indicated altitude is equal to the pressure altitude.

83.title: Which of the factors below increases the density altitude of an airport?

variants.c: Decrease of relative humidity of the air.

84.title: Under what condition is indicated altitude the same as true altitude?

variants.a: When at sea level under standard conditions.
variants.b: If the altimeter has no mechanical error.
variants.c: With the altimeter set at 1013.2 hPa.

85.title: If the outside air temperature (OAT) at a given altitude is lower than standard, the density altitude is

variants.b: Lower than pressure altitude and approximately equal to true altitude.
variants.c: Higher than true altitude and lower than pressure altitude.

variants.a: The pressure altitude corrected for nonstandard temperature.
variants.b: The height above the standard datum plane.
variants.c: The altitude read directly from the altimeter.

94.title: The density altitude could be approximately calculated from the pressure altitude without using a navigation calculator by

variants.a: Increasing/decreasing the pressure altitude by 120 ft for each °C deviation above/below the standard temperature.
variants.b: Increasing/decreasing the altitude above the sea level for the difference between the standard and actual atmospheric pressure, converted into an altitude.
variants.c: Increasing the pressure altitude by 4% for each 10°C deviation from the standard temperature.

95.title: Which of the statements below, concerning take-off performance of a powered aircraft regarding the density altitude is correct? At higher density altitudes

variants.a: aircraft accelerate poorer, because of reduced engine and propeller efficiency.
variants.b: aircraft accelerate better, because of reduced drag due to thinner air.
variants.c: aircraft must fly at higher-than-normal indicated airspeed in order to produce enough lift.

96.title: How does higher air humidity affect aircraft take-off performance? Take-off distances are

97.title: Which combination of atmospheric conditions will reduce aircraft takeoff and climb performance?

variants.a: High temperature, high relative humidity and high density altitude.
variants.b: Low temperature, low relative humidity and low density altitude.
variants.c: High temperature, low relative humidity and low density altitude.
variants.d: Low temperature, high relative humidity and high density altitude.

98.title: What influence does the increased mass have on powered aircraft takeoff performance?

variants.a: At given engine power the aircraft accelerates poorer; the airspeed required for the production of the lift necessary for leaving the ground is greater.
variants.b: At given engine power the aircraft accelerates better, however the airspeed required for production of the lift necessary for lift-off remains unchanged.
variants.c: Each aircraft at given engine power accelerate equally regardless of the mass, however the airspeed required for overcoming the ground effect is greater.

100.title: What effect does high density altitude have on aircraft performance?

variants.c: When trying to climb without sacrificing cruising speed.
variants.d: When trying to get cruising altitude quickly.

variants.a: When trying to get cruising altitude quickly.
variants.d: When trying to avoid an excessive pitch altitude during a climb.

106.title: What is the influence of the wind on an aeroplane's rate of climb?

variants.b: A headwind will increase the rate of climb.
variants.c: A tailwind will decrease the rate of climb.
variants.d: A tailwind will increase the rate of climb.

107.title: What influence does the wind have on an airplane's angle-of-climb?

variants.a: A headwind will steepen the angle-of-climb.
variants.c: A headwind will lessen the angle-of-climb.
variants.d: A tailwind will steepen the angle-of-climb.

110.title: During landing on an airport with high elevation the true air speed (TAS) of an aircraft is higher than normal. What indicated speed (IAS) should be kept in such cases?

variants.d: Increased for 5 kts for each 1,000 ft of airport elevation.

111.title: Should you use the normal approach speed when approaching to land in gusty wind conditions?

variants.a: No. Add one half the "gust factor" to the calculated approach speed.

112.title: Maximum structural cruising speed is the maximum speed at which an airplane can be operated

113.title: Why should speeds in flight above Vne be avoided?

variants.a: The design limit factor may be exceeded, if gusts are encountered.
variants.b: Excessive induced drag will result in a structural failure.
variants.c: Control effectiveness is so impaired that the aircraft becomes uncontrollable.

114.title: Which maximum range factors decreases as weight decreases?

116.title: Maneuvering speed (Va) is the highest speed at which even full abrupt deflection of the elevator will not exceed

117.title: How will higher altitude affect the cruising indicated airspeed of an aircraft if a throttle remains unchanged?

118.title: What does "Best Endurance Speed" for a propeller aircraft mean?

variants.a: Maximum time aloft per unit of fuel (flying with least power).
variants.b: Maximum distance per unit of fuel (flying with least drag).

133.title: Approximately what engine RPM should be set during cruising at the pressure altitude 2,000 ft and with standard temperature in order to develop 60% of power?

134.title:
What is the expected fuel consumption under the following conditions? 
pressure altitude  8,000 ft 
temperature  20°C below standard 
power setting  55%

135.title: Which forward speed is normally maintained, following an engine failure in flight in a light airplane?

136.title: The forward speed for minimum rate of descent of an aircraft, compared with its best glide speed, is

137.title: What should be done first, following an aircraft's engine failure in flight?

variants.a: Select the gliding altitude with best glide speed.
variants.c: Move the mixture lever to position FULL RICH.
variants.d: Select a suitable field for forced landing.

138.title: An aircraft without an engine will fly the longest distance from a given altitude at the angle of attack at which

variants.a: are induced drag and parasite drag equal.
variants.c: is parasite drag equal to lift coefficient.

139.title: Frost on the wings of an airplane may

variants.a: make it difficult or impossible to become airborne.
variants.b: cause the airplane to become airborne with a lower angle of attack and at a lower indicated airspeed.
variants.c: present no problem since frost will blow off when the aircraft starts moving during takeoff.
variants.d: change the camber (curvature of the wing) thereby increasing lift during takeoff.

140.title: What is the main danger arising out of even a slight amount of frost or snow on the wings and controls of an aircraft?

variants.a: Decrease lift due to irregular airflow over the wings.
variants.b: Increased weight due to ice will increase stall speed.
variants.c: Ice and snow will jam control surfaces.

142.title: What is the crosswind component for a landing on Runway 18 if the tower reports the wind as 220°/30 kts?

143.title: Which runway (06, 14, 24, 32) will you choose for landing, if tower reports south wind 20 kts and if maximum allowed crosswind component for your aircraft is 13 kts?

144.title: With the reported wind of 360°/20 kts you are approaching an airport. Which runway (06,14 or 24) would you choose for landing, if your airplane had a 13-knots maximum allowed crosswind component on landing?

145.title: What are the headwind and crosswind components with the reported wind of 280°/15 kts for a runway with the magnetic direction 220°?

146.title: Determine the maximum wind velocity for a 45° crosswind if the maximum crosswind component for the airplane is 25 kts?

147.title: Determine the maximum wind velocity for a 40° crosswind if the maximum crosswind component for the airplane is 10 kts?

148.title: Determine the maximum wind velocity for a 30° crosswind if the maximum crosswind component for the airplane is 10 kts?

149.title: What are the headwind and crosswind components with the reported wind of 030°/10 kts for a runway with the magnetic direction 330°?

150.title: What are the headwind and crosswind components with the reported wind of 130°/20 kts for a runway with the magnetic direction 040°?

variants.a: Zero headwind component; crosswind component 20 kts.
